children.subject:
In terms of managing workloads (and considering your interests), this would be a good schedule:

Fall: 61C, 188, EECS 126

Spring: 162, 161, 189
would advise against 162 and 189 in the same semseter, regardless of instructor. However, I do know people that have done it, and just not have time to enjoy themselves.

^+1 on what Kazu said

That sounds absolutely miserable unless maybe if you were a god.. but then you wouldn't be asking this anyways...
I'd have to either take 61c and 162 together or 162 and 189 together, or I just don't take 189. Sad lyfe. Definitely not a God in CS lol.
I only need 4 more upper divs so I can P/NP 162 or 189 if that helps.

I guess you should ask yourself, do you really want to learn machine learning? Or you "want" to learn because of all the hype, money, and  jobs.  Fine if you actually do, but maybe you can reconsider if you are just riding the bandwagon? Not saying that you are, just be honest with yourself. I know for one that I'd be lying to myself if I said I wanted to take it and all that hype wasn't influencing my decision.

Haha don't think Machine Learning can be self studied. I would suggest you to take 126 in Fall and then take 189 in Spring if you can (it is with Shewchuck so it could be slightly less challenging), and you should be okay, I believe. The classes you have listed for ML are just suggested prereqs, not hard requirements by any means. They are required if you want make the most out of 189 and get an A+-level understanding, but you can definitely take 189 without most of them, given that you don't have the time and you just want to learn about it (since Web Dev seems to be your major interest).

Also, CS 186 is Databases, not "Full Stack" and wouldn't help you much with your interest in Web Dev.

history.content:
Out of the classes you've listed above, I would say that:

  • 61C is heavy (but you have to take it, no choice there)
  • 188 is a self-studyable class, and doesn't help much with 189 tbh
  • 162 covers a lot of crucial topics in software engineering from what I've heard
  • 186 also covers some of the ideas in 162 (caching, concurrency) in a database setting, but doesn't have a lot to do with WebDev
  • Similarly, 168 is a class in how the Internet is built; very interesting, but not very useful for web dev
  • ML: You should take 126 before 189, if you can; when I took it with Shewchuk, it wasn't a pre-req, but 126 is still very good prep for 189.
  • 161: Very interesting class, with fun projects; while 61C is a prereq, could just as easily take both concurrently
  • 169: Also an interesting class from what I've heard, but a lot of the material is something you pick up during an internship/when you start working

With that in mind, I would suggest:
Fall: 61C, 161, 126

Spring: 189, 162  OR 189, 186, <insert-any-other-class that's not too heavy here>

Note I don't think it's a good idea to take 3 techs if two of them are 189 and 162.

I haven't taken:
Lower-Div: 61C
Artificial Intelligence: 188 (Can take edX course after graduation)
Essential: 162 (Heard it's not worth it, also heard it's essential)
Full Stack: 186 (Useful since i'm interested in Web Dev)
Internet: 168 (i'm interested in Web Dev)
Machine Learning: 16B, Math 110, EECS 126, EECS 127, CS 189(Unsure how to start)
Security: 161 (Interested in learning more about it)
Software Engineering: 169 (Practical knowledge)

I plan on taking 3 techs per semester. Any recommendations?

Following my intuition, i'd probably take:
Fall:
61c 168 188 Spring:
162 161 186 I wanted to learn Machine Learning but I suppose I can self study since I won't have time to take all the courses.
